description:
Human papillomavirus 32 (HPV32) is a member of the Papillomaviridae family, a group of small, non-enveloped DNA viruses that primarily infect the epithelial cells of the skin and mucous membranes. HPV32 is classified as a low-risk HPV type, meaning it is less likely to cause the development of cancerous lesions compared to high-risk HPV types.

HPV32 is commonly found in benign skin warts, particularly on the hands and feet. These warts, known as common warts or verrucae, are typically non-cancerous and can be treated through various methods, such as cryotherapy or topical treatments.

The viral genome of HPV32 is a circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that encodes several essential proteins responsible for viral replication, transcription, and the formation of the viral capsid. HPV32 infection is typically acquired through direct skin-to-skin contact or contact with contaminated surfaces.

While HPV32 infections are generally less concerning than infections with high-risk HPV types, it is still important to monitor and properly manage any skin lesions that may be caused by this virus, as they can potentially lead to discomfort or cosmetic concerns.
